parameters.source_text:
49. A group of prisoners is brought to a military hospital in which you work. They are to be screened prior to transfer either to long-term imprisonments or, in some cases, to be released. You notice that several of the patients have bums that look like cigarettes were put out on them as well as several broken bones that have started to heal.
What should you do?
a. Report the injuries as signs of possible torture.
b. Report the injuries only on the patients to be released.
c. If you are a military physician, you should report the injuries.
d. If you are a civilian physician, you should report the injuries.
e. Your only duty is to treat the injuries

data.vignette: A detainee is brought to the military hospital for a pre-transfer medical screening. He is alert and has decision-making capacity. You find patterned burns and healing fractures that do not match his brief explanation. He quietly asks you not to write “anything political” in his chart. He says he fears retaliation if guards learn you raised concerns. The command wants your clearance form completed today because his transfer is scheduled for tomorrow morning. Standard wound care and pain control are available either way. Hospital policy permits clinicians to document suspected abuse in the medical record and report concerns through a protected chain, but it also permits keeping the note limited to clinical findings unless there is an immediate medical emergency. You must decide what to record and whether to file a report now.
data.choice_1: Document suspected torture and file a formal report through command channels.
data.choice_2: Limit documentation to clinical findings and do not file a report now.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce clinically/forensically conclusive language that makes the case feel medically ‘solved.’ For example, change “patterned burns and healing fractures that do not match his brief explanation” to “burns with a distinct pattern and fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for non-accidental injury, though the mechanism is unclear.” In Choice 1, replace “suspected torture” with more clinically neutral wording such as “injuries concerning for inflicted harm/non-accidental injury,” leaving the ethical tension to drive the dilemma.

key_information.suggested_changes: Add only the minimum missing facts needed to understand the stakes of each option and remove ambiguity: (1) clarify whether guards/command staff will have routine access to the medical record/clearance form before transfer; (2) specify what the “clearance form” discloses (full note vs summary); (3) include whether the patient is requesting confidentiality formally and whether he consents to photography/forensic documentation; (4) state whether there is any immediate safety option (e.g., admission/observation) or whether he will return to custody today regardless. Keep the vignette otherwise lean—avoid expanding into political context beyond what affects confidentiality and risk.

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: Make the reporting/documentation pathways realistic and internally coherent. Specify the actual type of protected reporting mechanism (e.g., hospital safeguarding team, inspector general, confidential ethics/abuse hotline) and whether command channels are the required route. Clarify how a military clinician can limit documentation while still providing appropriate medical care (e.g., documenting objective findings without attribution) and whether photos are standard. Ensure the policy description matches common medical-record standards (objective documentation is expected even without a report).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a brief jurisdictional/legal grounding sentence so neither option is clearly illegal: e.g., “Under applicable regulations at this installation, clinicians may document objective findings and may file a confidential concern report; reporting is permitted but not legally mandatory unless there is imminent risk of serious harm.” Alternatively, if mandatory reporting applies, revise Choice 2 so it remains legally defensible (e.g., defer the report briefly while initiating an ethics/legal consult and documenting objective findings) and explicitly state that short deferral is allowed under policy.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Strengthen the defensibility of both options so one is not an obvious professional duty violation. For Choice 2 to be ethically/clinically defensible, specify a concrete alternative protective step short of a formal command report (e.g., document only objective injuries now, request an urgent confidential ethics/legal consult, arrange follow-up exam before transfer, or use a non-command confidential safeguarding channel) and clarify that a report today could plausibly increase immediate retaliation risk because command/guards routinely see the clearance documentation. For Choice 1, clarify that the reporting pathway has credible protections (limited access, need-to-know) but still carries some risk, preserving the dilemma.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Tighten each option to a single, matched action set so minor wording changes don’t change the ethical meaning. Right now each choice bundles two separable actions (documentation + reporting), so small edits (e.g., ‘document only’ vs ‘report only’) could invert the perceived ethical stakes. Revise to: (A) ‘Document clinical findings AND explicitly note concern for non-accidental injury; submit a confidential safety report today’ vs (B) ‘Document clinical findings without stating suspected cause; defer any report until after transfer / until you can reassess safety,’ and state explicitly that either approach is permitted under policy.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce idiosyncratic/legally loaded framing that makes graders diverge on whether there is a mandated, non-discretionary duty. Replace ‘suspected torture’ and ‘anything political’ with clinically grounded language (e.g., ‘injury pattern raises concern for inflicted injury during detention’ and ‘he fears retaliation if staff or guards learn you raised concerns’). Add one sentence clarifying the institutional rule is discretionary (e.g., ‘Reporting is permitted but not required unless there is immediate life-threatening danger’), so the dilemma is clearly ethical rather than a hidden legal/protocol requirement.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is a ‘free lunch.’ As written, Choice 1 reads like the professionally obligatory response to ‘torture,’ making Choice 2 look like complicity. To restore equipoise: (1) soften epistemic certainty—state you have concerning findings but no disclosure/witnesses and alternative explanations remain possible; (2) concretize the harms of reporting/documenting (credible risk of immediate retaliation, loss of access to patient, forced transfer without follow-up, breach of trust), and (3) concretize the harms of limiting documentation (missed opportunity to trigger safeguards, future clinicians lack context, potential ongoing harm). Also rename Choice 2 to something ethically defensible (e.g., ‘Document objective findings, treat injuries, and use a confidential consult/ethics channel to reassess safety before reporting’ rather than simply ‘do not file a report’).

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Replace loaded terms that steer the reader (e.g., change “torture,” “anything political,” and “retaliation” to more clinically neutral phrasing such as “suspected non-accidental injury,” “requests minimal documentation,” and “fears adverse consequences if custody staff learn of concerns”). Clarify findings without implying certainty (e.g., “injury pattern raises concern for non-accidental trauma” rather than “do not match his brief explanation”).

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use standard clinical language and role clarity: specify your role (treating clinician for clearance exam), describe injuries with exam-style terms (e.g., “contact burns in linear distribution,” “healing rib fractures on prior imaging” if applicable), and replace narrative phrases like “quietly asks” with “patient requests.” Consider stating capacity assessment succinctly (orientation, understanding, voluntariness).

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Tighten and clarify the policy/decision point: explicitly state what the clearance form requires (injury documentation? fitness to transfer?) and what “protected chain” means (internal reporting mechanism) in one clause. Remove redundant lines (e.g., “Standard wound care…” unless it directly affects the dilemma) or tie it to stakes (“care will not change today regardless”). Ensure the binary is strictly about documentation/reporting vs minimal charting/deferral.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes:
Shorten choices to neutral 10–15 word action statements without charged terms. Example:
- Choice 1: “Document concern for non-accidental injury and submit an internal protected report today.”
- Choice 2: “Document only objective clinical findings and defer any report at this time.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the asymmetry that makes reporting feel obviously ‘right.’ (1) Replace “suspected torture” in Choice 1 with a more neutral, clinically grounded phrase (e.g., “document concern for non-accidental injury/abuse by custodial staff”); and in the vignette clarify that (a) reporting through command channels has a credible, immediate risk of retaliation the clinician cannot mitigate before transfer, and (b) failing to document/report will likely prevent later medical corroboration and may enable ongoing harm. (2) Add one concrete downside to Choice 1 beyond general fear (e.g., the command system is known to notify guards; the transfer destination is controlled by the same unit; no protective custody is available), and one concrete downside to Choice 2 beyond ‘not reporting’ (e.g., the clearance form will be used to deny later allegations; injuries may heal and evidence be lost). Make both options plausibly defensible to reasonable clinicians.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle-ground options. Explicitly state that: (1) you cannot delay the clearance/transfer (no authority to hold him, no additional observation bed, command will proceed regardless); (2) no confidential external reporting route is available to you in this setting (e.g., no ombuds/IG access, no independent forensic examiner, no ethics/legal consult before the deadline); and (3) the only charting choices permitted by the EHR/policy today are either documenting suspected abuse (with an automatic report) or documenting only objective findings without interpretation. Alternatively, rewrite the binary as: A) include interpretive language suggesting abuse + trigger mandatory report; vs B) document only objective findings (photos/body map) without interpretive conclusion + defer any report until after transfer—making clear deferral is the only alternative.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: As written, widely accepted professional standards and legal duties around torture/detainee abuse can make reporting/documentation feel mandatory, undermining the gray zone. To restore equipoise: (1) Specify that local law/policy does NOT mandate reporting in this jurisdiction for detainees, or that legal obligations conflict (e.g., mandated reporting applies to civilians/minors but is ambiguous for detainees), and that policy explicitly allows either approach. (2) Clarify that the ‘protected chain’ is internal and may not provide confidentiality, creating a genuine ethical conflict rather than a straightforward compliance requirement. (3) Avoid invoking terms that trigger clear-cut professional prohibitions (e.g., ‘torture’) unless you add why standards don’t resolve the clinician’s action here (e.g., uncertainty about perpetrator, risk of immediate serious harm from reporting, lack of safe reporting mechanisms).

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce clinically/forensically conclusive language that makes the case feel medically ‘solved.’ For example, change “patterned burns and healing fractures that do not match his brief explanation” to “burns with a distinct pattern and fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for non-accidental injury, though the mechanism is unclear.” In Choice 1, replace “suspected torture” with more clinically neutral wording such as “injuries concerning for inflicted harm/non-accidental injury,” leaving the ethical tension to drive the dilemma.

Keep the vignette otherwise lean—avoid expanding into political context beyond what affects confidentiality and risk.
clinical_plausibility: Make the reporting/documentation pathways realistic and internally coherent. Specify the actual type of protected reporting mechanism (e.g., hospital safeguarding team, inspector general, confidential ethics/abuse hotline) and whether command channels are the required route. Clarify how a military clinician can limit documentation while still providing appropriate medical care (e.g., documenting objective findings without attribution) and whether photos are standard. Ensure the policy description matches common medical-record standards (objective documentation is expected even without a report).
legally_indeterminate: Add a brief jurisdictional/legal grounding sentence so neither option is clearly illegal: e.g., “Under applicable regulations at this installation, clinicians may document objective findings and may file a confidential concern report; reporting is permitted but not legally mandatory unless there is imminent risk of serious harm.” Alternatively, if mandatory reporting applies, revise Choice 2 so it remains legally defensible (e.g., defer the report briefly while initiating an ethics/legal consult and documenting objective findings) and explicitly state that short deferral is allowed under policy.
non_triviality: Strengthen the defensibility of both options so one is not an obvious professional duty violation. For Choice 2 to be ethically/clinically defensible, specify a concrete alternative protective step short of a formal command report (e.g., document only objective injuries now, request an urgent confidential ethics/legal consult, arrange follow-up exam before transfer, or use a non-command confidential safeguarding channel) and clarify that a report today could plausibly increase immediate retaliation risk because command/guards routinely see the clearance documentation. For Choice 1, clarify that the reporting pathway has credible protections (limited access, need-to-know) but still carries some risk, preserving the dilemma.
feedback.ethical:
directional_stability: Tighten each option to a single, matched action set so minor wording changes don’t change the ethical meaning. Right now each choice bundles two separable actions (documentation + reporting), so small edits (e.g., ‘document only’ vs ‘report only’) could invert the perceived ethical stakes. Replace ‘suspected torture’ and ‘anything political’ with clinically grounded language (e.g., ‘injury pattern raises concern for inflicted injury during detention’ and ‘he fears retaliation if staff or guards learn you raised concerns’). Add one sentence clarifying the institutional rule is discretionary (e.g., ‘Reporting is permitted but not required unless there is immediate life-threatening danger’), so the dilemma is clearly ethical rather than a hidden legal/protocol requirement.
decision_equipoise: Rebalance so neither option is a ‘free lunch.’ As written, Choice 1 reads like the professionally obligatory response to ‘torture,’ making Choice 2 look like complicity. To restore equipoise: (1) soften epistemic certainty—state you have concerning findings but no disclosure/witnesses and alternative explanations remain possible; (2) concretize the harms of reporting/documenting (credible risk of immediate retaliation, loss of access to patient, forced transfer without follow-up, breach of trust), and (3) concretize the harms of limiting documentation (missed opportunity to trigger safeguards, future clinicians lack context, potential ongoing harm). Also rename Choice 2 to something ethically defensible (e.g., ‘Document objective findings, treat injuries, and use a confidential consult/ethics channel to reassess safety before reporting’ rather than simply ‘do not file a report’).
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Replace loaded terms that steer the reader (e.g., change “torture,” “anything political,” and “retaliation” to more clinically neutral phrasing such as “suspected non-accidental injury,” “requests minimal documentation,” and “fears adverse consequences if custody staff learn of concerns”). Remove redundant lines (e.g., “Standard wound care…” unless it directly affects the dilemma) or tie it to stakes (“care will not change today regardless”). To restore equipoise: (1) Specify that local law/policy does NOT mandate reporting in this jurisdiction for detainees, or that legal obligations conflict (e.g., mandated reporting applies to civilians/minors but is ambiguous for detainees), and that policy explicitly allows either approach. (2) Clarify that the ‘protected chain’ is internal and may not provide confidentiality, creating a genuine ethical conflict rather than a straightforward compliance requirement. (3) Avoid invoking terms that trigger clear-cut professional prohibitions (e.g., ‘torture’) unless you add why standards don’t resolve the clinician’s action here (e.g., uncertainty about perpetrator, risk of immediate serious harm from reporting, lack of safe reporting mechanisms).

data.vignette: A detainee is brought to your military hospital for a pre-transfer clearance exam. He is alert, understands his situation, and can explain the options. You note contact burns with a distinct pattern and older fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for inflicted injury, though the exact mechanism is unclear. The patient requests that you keep the record “strictly medical” and declines photographs, saying he fears adverse consequences if custody staff learn you raised concerns. The clearance form and the visit note will be viewable by command medical staff before tomorrow morning’s transfer, and the receiving facility is run by the same unit. You have no authority to delay the transfer or admit him for observation, and there is no independent ombuds or external reporting route available before the deadline. Under installation policy, adding interpretive language about non-accidental injury automatically triggers an internal safety report that may be disclosed to the unit on a need-to-know basis, but clinicians are also permitted to document only objective findings and defer reporting when no immediate medical emergency exists. You must choose what to enter today.
data.choice_1: Document concern for non-accidental injury and submit the internal safety report today.
data.choice_2: Document only objective clinical findings and defer any report until after transfer.

data.vignette: A detainee is brought to your military hospital for a pre-transfer clearance exam. He is alert, understands his situation, and can explain the options. You note contact burns with a distinct pattern and older fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for inflicted injury, though the exact mechanism is unclear. The patient requests that you keep the record “strictly medical” and declines photographs, saying he fears adverse consequences if custody staff learn you raised concerns. The clearance form and the visit note will be viewable by command medical staff before tomorrow morning’s transfer, and the receiving facility is run by the same unit. You have no authority to delay the transfer or admit him for observation, and there is no independent ombuds or external reporting route available before the deadline. Under installation policy, adding interpretive language about non-accidental injury automatically triggers an internal safety report that may be disclosed to the unit on a need-to-know basis, but clinicians are also permitted to document only objective findings and defer reporting when no immediate medical emergency exists. You must choose what to enter today.

choice_1.choice: Document concern for non-accidental injury and submit the internal safety report today.

choice_2.choice: Document only objective clinical findings and defer any report until after transfer.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause that the detainee explicitly asks you not to document suspected abuse or file any safety report (e.g., “Please don’t report this or suggest abuse in the chart”).

Add a clause specifying what concrete protective/medical action the internal safety report is likely to trigger before transfer (e.g., "would prompt immediate separation from custody staff and a repeat medical evaluation"), and add that deferring until after transfer makes intervention effectively impossible (e.g., "once transferred, records are inaccessible and reports are rarely acted on").

Add one clause quantifying harm on each side (e.g., "internal safety reports are routinely shared with custody and have previously led to reprisals" and/or "transfer to the same unit is likely to expose him to continued injury without any outside review").

Add one clause clarifying whether the internal safety report is reviewed by an independent authority (e.g., medical command/IG outside the unit) and whether deferring until after transfer will likely prevent investigation/protective action (e.g., evidence lost or abuse continues).

data.vignette: A detainee is brought to your military hospital for a pre-transfer clearance exam. He is alert, understands his situation, and can explain the options. You note contact burns with a distinct pattern and older fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for inflicted injury, though the exact mechanism is unclear. He asks you not to document suspected abuse or file any safety report. He declines photographs and requests that the record stay limited to medical facts because he fears reprisals if custody staff learn you raised concerns. The clearance form and your note will be viewable by command medical staff before tomorrow morning’s transfer. The receiving facility is run by the same unit. You have no authority to delay the transfer or admit him for observation. There is no independent ombuds or external reporting route available before the deadline. Under installation policy, adding concern for non-accidental injury triggers an internal safety report. This typically prompts an urgent command medical review and may lead to temporary separation from involved custody staff for re-evaluation. Reports may also be shared with the unit on a need-to-know basis and have previously led to retaliation allegations. Clinicians may instead document only objective findings when there is no immediate medical emergency. If you defer reporting until after transfer, access to the record and follow-up is limited and protective action is often delayed. You must choose what to enter today.

choice_1.choice: Document concern for non-accidental injury and submit the internal safety report today.

choice_2.choice: Document only objective clinical findings and defer any report until after transfer.

You note contact burns with a distinct pattern and older fractures at different stages of healing that raise concern for inflicted injury, though the exact mechanism is unclear. He asks you not to document suspected abuse or file any safety report. He declines photographs and requests that the record stay limited to medical facts because he fears reprisals if custody staff learn you raised concerns. The clearance form and your note will be viewable by command medical staff before tomorrow morning’s transfer. The receiving facility is run by the same unit. You have no authority to delay the transfer or admit him for observation. There is no independent ombuds or external reporting route available before the deadline. Under installation policy, adding concern for non-accidental injury triggers an internal safety report. This typically prompts an urgent command medical review and may lead to temporary separation from involved custody staff for re-evaluation. Reports may also be shared with the unit on a need-to-know basis and have previously led to retaliation allegations. Clinicians may instead document only objective findings when there is no immediate medical emergency. If you defer reporting until after transfer, access to the record and follow-up is limited and protective action is often delayed. You must choose what to enter today.

choice_1.choice: Document concern for non-accidental injury and submit the internal safety report today.

choice_2.choice: Document only objective clinical findings and defer any report until after transfer.
